statement:
Let $\Sigma$ be a fixed signature, and ${\mathfrak{A}}$ and
${\mathfrak{B}}$ two structures for $\Sigma$. If
$f\colon {\mathfrak{A}}\to {\mathfrak{B}}$ is a homomorphism, then
$\ker(f)$ is a congruence on ${\mathfrak{A}}$.

If $F$ is an $n$-ary function symbol of $\Sigma$, and
$f(a_i) = f(a_i')$, then $$\begin{aligned}
 f(F^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1, \ldots, a_n)) &= F^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1), \ldots, f(a_n)) \\
 &= F^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1'), \ldots, f(a_n')) \\
 &= f(F^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1', \ldots, a_n')). \qedhere
 \end{aligned}$$
names: kernel of a homomorphism is a congruence
